The TGA aims to improve patient safety with this decision.
The move will impact the availability of certain vitamin B6 products.

clusters.title: System failed our daughter, say parents, as NHS trust fined £200,000 over death
clusters.neutral_headline: System failed our daughter, say parents, as NHS trust fined £200,000 over death: Ellame Ford-Dunn, 16, who had mental health problems, absconded from a ward and killed herself shortly afterwardsA girl who killed herself when she absconded from 24-hour clinical supervision was failed by a system that was meant to protect her, her parents have said, after the NHS trust involved was fined over the avoidable death.Ellame Ford-Dunn, 16, who suffered with severe mental health problems, died on 20 March 2022, minutes after leaving the Bluefin acute children’s ward in Worthing hospital, part of University hospitals Sussex NHS trust (UHSussex). Continue reading

Ellame Ford-Dunn, 16, with mental health issues, died after absconding.
She left a ward and died shortly after, under 24-hour supervision.
Her parents stated the system failed to protect her.
The incident occurred at University Hospitals Sussex NHS trust.

clusters.title: Shortfall in return on investment in health | Brief letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Shortfall in return on investment in health | Brief letters: Great Western Park health centre | Cricket headlines | UK emissions | Quick Crossword | Air guitarLord Hutton writes of the NHS health centres that have been built thanks to private finance (Letters, 23 November). In Didcot we’ve been waiting more than 10 years for the Great Western Park health centre. The return on investment required by the developer is greater than the NHS will reimburse. The local integrated care board fears that at that cost they’ll not get a GP practice to take on the health centre.Cllr Sarah JamesVale of White Horse district council• Congratulations on the print-edition headline “Lights, Canberra, no action”, about England’s beaten cricketers not playing in the Australian capital (24 November). It reminded me of my all-time favourite in the Guardian when Zaheer Abbas began the county cricket season in 1981 by scoring 1,000 runs in one month: “Happy days Zaheer again”. Genius.Mark GarrodPotters Bar, Hertfordshire Continue reading

ai_summary: A health center in Didcot has been delayed over return on investment.
The developer's required return exceeds NHS reimbursement.
The local care board fears they cannot secure a GP practice.
The letter also discusses a cricket headline from the Guardian.
The letter writer recalls a favorite Guardian headline from 1981.

clusters.title: ‘My mother had dementia but beautiful things unfolded’: Cheryle St Onge’s best photograph
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘My mother had dementia but beautiful things unfolded’: Cheryle St Onge’s best photograph: ‘She wasn’t very fond of Skipper, our jack russell, who loved the hose. But they were dancing together – two beings in the afternoon sunlight, having their own conversation’I am an only child. My father was killed in a car accident when I was 14 and my mother was 47. We were really tightly bonded after that. She worked at a university and was an artist: she painted and carved birds. She was a wonderful person, who lit up a room and was someone everyone wanted to be around. She was very giving.Later in life, she developed dementia. I left my teaching position to stay home and look after her. She was very active – she would go outside and rip up bulbs, put the horses in the wrong stalls. It was very stressful to come home – I would enter the driveway and think: “Oh my word!” Continue reading

The daughter cared for her mother after she developed dementia.
The mother had a close bond with her daughter.
The article features a photograph of the mother and dog.

clusters.title: Vitamin supplements with high levels of B6 will be removed from general sale in Australia – here’s what you need to know
clusters.neutral_headline: Vitamin B6 Supplements Removed From Sale in Australia

items.title: Vitamin supplements with high levels of B6 will be removed from general sale in Australia – here’s what you need to know
items.standfirst: As the Therapeutic Goods Administration takes action, what should you do until the rules come into force?Australia’s drug regulator has ordered that supplements with high levels of vitamin B6 be removed from general sale in response to hundreds of reports of nerve damage and other side-effects linked to long-term use.From June 2027 any vitamin B6 product containing more than 50mg in each recommended daily dose will be moved behind the pharmacy counter. The recommended dietary intake of vitamin B6 for a healthy adult is just 1.3mg to 1.7mg a day. Continue reading...
items.content: As the Therapeutic Goods Administration takes action, what should you do until the rules come into force?Australia’s drug regulator has ordered that supplements with high levels of vitamin B6 be removed from general sale in response to hundreds of reports of nerve damage and other side-effects linked to long-term use.From June 2027 any vitamin B6 product containing more than 50mg in each recommended daily dose will be moved behind the pharmacy counter. The recommended dietary intake of vitamin B6 for a healthy adult is just 1.3mg to 1.7mg a day. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Australia will remove high-dose vitamin B6 supplements from general sale.
The Therapeutic Goods Administration ordered the change due to side effects.
Supplements with over 50mg per dose will be behind pharmacy counters.
The recommended daily intake of B6 is 1.3mg to 1.7mg for adults.
The change is effective from June 2027.

clusters.title: UK politics: No 10 says no final decisions after leak reveals jury trials might be scrapped except for alleged rapists and killers – as it happened
clusters.neutral_headline: UK Government Considers Jury Trial Changes

items.title: UK politics: No 10 says no final decisions after leak reveals jury trials might be scrapped except for alleged rapists and killers – as it happened
items.standfirst: Downing Street does not deny that justice secretary, David Lammy, is considering scrapping juries for most trialsJohn McFall is standing down early as Lord Speaker in the House of Lords so that he can care for his wife, Joan, who has was Parkinson’s. According to Sam Blewett and Bethany Dawson in their London Playbook briefing for Politico, the main candidates to replace him are Michael Forsyth, a rightwing Scottish secretary in the final two years of the John Major government, and Deborah Bull, a crossbencher and former Royal Opera House creative director. They reports:Labour isn’t expected to put forward a candidate as McFall’s previous political affiliation means it’s seen as another party’s turn to rule the roost, Noah [Keate] writes in to say. Forsyth has garnered support from some Labour grandees who like his traditional approach and aversion to modernization while Bull has being promoted by some female peers keen for a woman to take charge. One Tory peer described Forsyth as a “political animal” who may struggle to encourage a consensus across the chamber. A list of candidates’ register of interests and election addresses (up to 300 words) will be emailed to all peers on Dec. 1. Watch your inboxes!Transport secretary Heidi Alexander rejected a rival proposal from Arora Group, saying Heathrow’s own plans were “the most credible and deliverable option”.The Heathrow proposals involve building a 3,500-metre runway and require a new M25 tunnel and bridges to be built 130 metres west of the existing motorway.Following a comparative assessment of the remaining proposals for Heathrow expansion, the government’s view is that the Northwest runway scheme brought forward by Heathrow Airport Limited offers the most credible and deliverable option, principally due to the relative maturity of its proposal, the comparative level of confidence in the feasibility and resilience of its surface access plans, and the stronger comfort it provides in relation to the efficient, resilient and sustainable operations of the airport over the long-term.The HAL scheme is considered comparatively more mature in its approach to road infrastructure. While the HAL scheme requires major works to the M25, assessment indicates that the HWL scheme would also have a considerable impact on the M25. Continue reading...
items.content: Downing Street does not deny that justice secretary, David Lammy, is considering scrapping juries for most trialsJohn McFall is standing down early as Lord Speaker in the House of Lords so that he can care for his wife, Joan, who has was Parkinson’s. According to Sam Blewett and Bethany Dawson in their London Playbook briefing for Politico, the main candidates to replace him are Michael Forsyth, a rightwing Scottish secretary in the final two years of the John Major government, and Deborah Bull, a crossbencher and former Royal Opera House creative director. They reports:Labour isn’t expected to put forward a candidate as McFall’s previous political affiliation means it’s seen as another party’s turn to rule the roost, Noah [Keate] writes in to say. Forsyth has garnered support from some Labour grandees who like his traditional approach and aversion to modernization while Bull has being promoted by some female peers keen for a woman to take charge. One Tory peer described Forsyth as a “political animal” who may struggle to encourage a consensus across the chamber. A list of candidates’ register of interests and election addresses (up to 300 words) will be emailed to all peers on Dec. 1. Watch your inboxes!Transport secretary Heidi Alexander rejected a rival proposal from Arora Group, saying Heathrow’s own plans were “the most credible and deliverable option”.The Heathrow proposals involve building a 3,500-metre runway and require a new M25 tunnel and bridges to be built 130 metres west of the existing motorway.Following a comparative assessment of the remaining proposals for Heathrow expansion, the government’s view is that the Northwest runway scheme brought forward by Heathrow Airport Limited offers the most credible and deliverable option, principally due to the relative maturity of its proposal, the comparative level of confidence in the feasibility and resilience of its surface access plans, and the stronger comfort it provides in relation to the efficient, resilient and sustainable operations of the airport over the long-term.The HAL scheme is considered comparatively more mature in its approach to road infrastructure. While the HAL scheme requires major works to the M25, assessment indicates that the HWL scheme would also have a considerable impact on the M25. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Downing Street did not deny considering scrapping jury trials.
The Justice Secretary, David Lammy, is considering the changes.
The Lord Speaker is stepping down to care for his wife.
Candidates to replace the Lord Speaker are being considered.
Heathrow's runway expansion plans are considered most credible.

Some packaged coffees will also be affected by the tax.
The tax aims to reduce sugar consumption in the UK.
The change will likely increase the cost of some beverages.

clusters.title: Covid inquiry lays bare unforgivable failures of Boris Johnson’s government | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Covid Inquiry Reveals Government Failures

items.title: Covid inquiry lays bare unforgivable failures of Boris Johnson’s government | Letters
items.standfirst: Readers respond to the official report on the handling of the pandemicRe your report (‘Too little, too late’: damning report condemns UK’s Covid response, 20 November), shortly after lockdown began, my family lost an aunt and uncle within an hour of each other to Covid in different hospitals in Manchester. Their son was in a third in A&E, also with Covid, but survived. Six months later my father, who was in hospital recuperating from major surgery, was rushed out of the building late at night because of a fear of Covid on the ward. Within two weeks, he died of Covid. On the day he died, my mother tested positive and spent the next two weeks grieving in isolation. I could not visit as I lived 200 miles away and respected the travel ban.At his funeral, we followed the rules, so a very small number of people could attend. My father was such a part of the local community that people lined the roads around the cemetery, everyone respecting social distancing. I could not hug my mother at the funeral because we were not in the same bubble. Continue reading...
items.content: Readers respond to the official report on the handling of the pandemicRe your report (‘Too little, too late’: damning report condemns UK’s Covid response, 20 November), shortly after lockdown began, my family lost an aunt and uncle within an hour of each other to Covid in different hospitals in Manchester. Their son was in a third in A&E, also with Covid, but survived. Six months later my father, who was in hospital recuperating from major surgery, was rushed out of the building late at night because of a fear of Covid on the ward. Within two weeks, he died of Covid. On the day he died, my mother tested positive and spent the next two weeks grieving in isolation. I could not visit as I lived 200 miles away and respected the travel ban.At his funeral, we followed the rules, so a very small number of people could attend. My father was such a part of the local community that people lined the roads around the cemetery, everyone respecting social distancing. I could not hug my mother at the funeral because we were not in the same bubble. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The report condemns the UK's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Readers share personal experiences of loss during the pandemic.
One family lost relatives to COVID-19 in a short time.
A father died of COVID-19 after surgery in the hospital.
The article highlights the impact of the pandemic on families.

clusters.title: I got an epidural for all three of my births – none of them worked as expected
clusters.neutral_headline: Epidurals Did Not Work as Expected

items.title: I got an epidural for all three of my births – none of them worked as expected
items.standfirst: Here’s what you should know before getting an epidural – and why it might not provide full pain relief as expectedThe first time I got an epidural, it was too late.I’d heard it was best to wait, for fear the medication would run out mid-labor (I later found out this is a myth). So I gritted my teeth through hours of contractions, and when I finally told the nurses I was ready, the anesthesiologist was with another patient. Continue reading...
items.content: Here’s what you should know before getting an epidural – and why it might not provide full pain relief as expectedThe first time I got an epidural, it was too late.I’d heard it was best to wait, for fear the medication would run out mid-labor (I later found out this is a myth). So I gritted my teeth through hours of contractions, and when I finally told the nurses I was ready, the anesthesiologist was with another patient. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author's epidurals did not provide full pain relief.
The first epidural was administered too late in labor.
The author waited due to fear of the medication running out.
The anesthesiologist was unavailable when the author was ready.
The article discusses the realities of epidural use.

clusters.title: The majority of doctors supported the recent strike. So why did the Department of Health suggest the opposite? | Peter Kellner
clusters.neutral_headline: Doctors Supported Strike, Polls Showed Otherwise

items.title: The majority of doctors supported the recent strike. So why did the Department of Health suggest the opposite? | Peter Kellner
items.standfirst: It would seem that poll data was cherrypicked and then used to brief the Times. Such distortion of facts from a public body should alarm us allThe latest strike by resident doctors began on Friday 14 November. That morning, the headline of the lead story on the front page of the Times proclaimed: “Five days of NHS strikes opposed by most doctors”.The story began: “Most junior doctors do not support Friday’s strike, a poll has revealed as Wes Streeting attacked the British Medical Association for going ‘against the wishes’ of its members.” The trouble is that the poll showed no such thing.Peter Kellner is a former president of YouGovDo you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading...
items.content: It would seem that poll data was cherrypicked and then used to brief the Times. Such distortion of facts from a public body should alarm us allThe latest strike by resident doctors began on Friday 14 November. That morning, the headline of the lead story on the front page of the Times proclaimed: “Five days of NHS strikes opposed by most doctors”.The story began: “Most junior doctors do not support Friday’s strike, a poll has revealed as Wes Streeting attacked the British Medical Association for going ‘against the wishes’ of its members.” The trouble is that the poll showed no such thing.Peter Kellner is a former president of YouGovDo you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A poll was used to suggest doctors opposed the recent strike.
The Times newspaper reported that most doctors opposed the strike.
The poll did not support the claim made in the article.
The poll data was allegedly cherry-picked and used.
The article raises concerns about the distortion of facts.

clusters.title: Antibiotic resistance: how a pioneering trial is using old drugs to save babies from sepsis
clusters.neutral_headline: Antibiotic Resistance: Old Drugs Save Babies

items.title: Antibiotic resistance: how a pioneering trial is using old drugs to save babies from sepsis
items.standfirst: The infection is responsible for 800,000 newborn deaths each year, but clinics in eight countries are working together to find new treatmentsJust a few minutes from the turquoise waters of Kenya’s Kilifi Creek, a world away from the tourists enjoying their time on the estuary, a team of clinicians, technicians and microbiologists is helping to shape a new era of care for newborns.NeoSep1 is a pioneering clinical trial that aims to identify effective and safe antibiotic combinations to treat sepsis in newborns. One of the centres leading the second phase of this study is the Kemri-Wellcome Trust Research Programme (KWTRP) in Kilifi. Continue reading...
items.content: The infection is responsible for 800,000 newborn deaths each year, but clinics in eight countries are working together to find new treatmentsJust a few minutes from the turquoise waters of Kenya’s Kilifi Creek, a world away from the tourists enjoying their time on the estuary, a team of clinicians, technicians and microbiologists is helping to shape a new era of care for newborns.NeoSep1 is a pioneering clinical trial that aims to identify effective and safe antibiotic combinations to treat sepsis in newborns. One of the centres leading the second phase of this study is the Kemri-Wellcome Trust Research Programme (KWTRP) in Kilifi. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A trial uses old drugs to save babies from sepsis.
Sepsis causes 800,000 newborn deaths annually.
Clinics in eight countries are working together.
The NeoSep1 trial aims to find new treatments.
The Kemri-Wellcome Trust Research Programme is involved.

clusters.title: Adolescence lasts into 30s - new study shows four pivotal ages for your brain
clusters.neutral_headline: Adolescence Extends into 30s, Study Shows

items.title: Adolescence lasts into 30s - new study shows four pivotal ages for your brain
items.standfirst: Brain scans on thousands of people reveal the dramatic shifts the brain goes through between birth and death.
items.content: Brain scans on thousands of people reveal the dramatic shifts the brain goes through between birth and death.

ai_summary: A new study shows adolescence extends into the 30s.
The study reveals four pivotal ages for the brain.
Brain scans were used on thousands of people.
The scans show dramatic brain shifts over time.
The article discusses brain development stages.

clusters.title: What is prostate cancer and how is it diagnosed in the UK?
clusters.neutral_headline: What is prostate cancer and how is it diagnosed in the UK?

items.title: What is prostate cancer and how is it diagnosed in the UK?
items.standfirst: As David Cameron receives treatment and backs calls for NHS screening, we look at the disease and its treatmentMore than 100 MPs urge Streeting to approve prostate cancer screeningDavid Cameron has become the latest high-profile figure to back growing calls for the NHS to start screening men, or at least those at highest risk, for prostate cancer after being treated for it himself.He joined Olympic cycling champion Chris Hoy and prostate cancer charities in saying that recent advances in diagnosing the disease mean that testing can be introduced that is much safer than traditional methods, which can produce both false-positive and false-negative results. Continue reading...
items.content: As David Cameron receives treatment and backs calls for NHS screening, we look at the disease and its treatmentMore than 100 MPs urge Streeting to approve prostate cancer screeningDavid Cameron has become the latest high-profile figure to back growing calls for the NHS to start screening men, or at least those at highest risk, for prostate cancer after being treated for it himself.He joined Olympic cycling champion Chris Hoy and prostate cancer charities in saying that recent advances in diagnosing the disease mean that testing can be introduced that is much safer than traditional methods, which can produce both false-positive and false-negative results. Continue reading...

items.title: More than 100 MPs urge Streeting to approve prostate cancer screening
items.standfirst: Rishi Sunak hands health secretary open letter calling for testing for men at the highest riskWhat is prostate cancer and how is it diagnosed in the UK?More than 100 MPs, including Rishi Sunak, have urged Wes Streeting to introduce screening for prostate cancer.The UK National Screening Committee, a government agency that advises ministers and the NHS about all aspects of screening, will recommend whether men at higher risk of the disease should be offered checks. It is due to write to the health secretary later this week, the Telegraph reported. Continue reading...
items.content: Rishi Sunak hands health secretary open letter calling for testing for men at the highest riskWhat is prostate cancer and how is it diagnosed in the UK?More than 100 MPs, including Rishi Sunak, have urged Wes Streeting to introduce screening for prostate cancer.The UK National Screening Committee, a government agency that advises ministers and the NHS about all aspects of screening, will recommend whether men at higher risk of the disease should be offered checks. It is due to write to the health secretary later this week, the Telegraph reported. Continue reading...

ai_summary: David Cameron is receiving treatment for prostate cancer.
He supports calls for NHS screening for the disease.
More than 100 MPs urge approval of prostate cancer screening.
Rishi Sunak handed a letter to the health secretary.
The UK National Screening Committee will make recommendations.

clusters.title: The species at risk of extinction named in UK-first report
clusters.neutral_headline: UK Report Identifies Thousands of Species Facing Extinction

items.title: The species at risk of extinction named in UK-first report
items.standfirst: Species in Peril identifies thousands of at-risk species in Wales based on geographical restriction.
items.content: Species in Peril identifies thousands of at-risk species in Wales based on geographical restriction.

ai_summary: A UK-first report, Species in Peril, details thousands of at-risk species in Wales.
The report assesses species based on geographical restriction within Wales.
The assessment considers factors like population size and habitat loss.
Many species are threatened due to climate change and habitat destruction.
Conservation efforts are needed to protect vulnerable species from extinction.
